inn1.comm: ooh and immediately Pollock finds a good length - finds some bounce, too - lifting on the left hander who just pulls his bat inside the line
a tighter line on off stump and it's carefully, cautiously pushed out on the back foot
reasonable pace, just around 80mph, and an even tighter line this time, cutting back into Bray who jumps back and defends off the back foot once more
a beauty! Bray would've done well to get an edge on that. Coming forward, he was beaten by one that just cut back on him - almost cutting him in half
but Bray is confidently forward onto the front foot, solidly defending
and it's left alone outside off
classical Ntini; wide of the crease, angling it across the left hander at pace. Too wide to trouble the batsman who sways out of the way. Good bounce first up, though
beaten. Again angling across the batsman, but a slightly fuller length drew him forward and, attempting to defend, he missed it by a whisker
oh that's a belter from Ntini; just a touch short of a length and, well, Porterfield probably withdrew his bat in time. We'll give him that
too short and wide, just a little scattergunnish from Ntini there
and Porterfield receives an angry, fierce glare from Ntini in his follow through. Left alone outside off
beaten once more! Terrific ball, slightly fuller and tighter on off stump. Again Porterfield was tempted into feeling for it, poking at it, and it flew through to Boucher
well bowled indeed. Ideal conditions for Pollock here, and he just cut this away from Bray who really felt for it outside off, just nibbling at it, not unlike a blind mouse in search of cheese
tries to work this off his pads to leg, and he sets off for a single - woops! No he doesn't, he turns on his heel - nearly rupturing his ankle in the process - and scampers back

terrific bowling from Pollock - that is absolutely plumb. Cutting back into Bray once more, and Bray is rather trapped on the crease - trying to come forward, but without much conviction - and that's taking out middle
and he's immediately off the mark, as are Ireland, whipping this off his pads down to fine leg
neat stroke; on leg stump, pushed through midwicket with pleasing timing
short, rising on the batsman who just sways out of the way. Just...
the wrong line from Ntini, gifting Ireland their first boundary of the day. A full, leg-side drifter which is easily plucked off his legs and down for fine leg
drifting across the batsman who leaves alone, in the style of Jack Russell
pushed out into the covers, and not with the greatest of conviction either
ooh, I'm loving that: a tighter line, and it just cuts away from the batsman who pulls his bat inside the line. Just.
and again - the pace is unsettling Ireland's batsman here. And the movement
and a confident stride forward from the batsman, shouldering arms, ends the over
clever shot, actually. Full on middle-stump, swinging into the batsman who adjusts at the very last minute, flicking it down to fine leg
excellent cricket all round. A perfect line and length, shaping back into the batsman who goes back and - head right over the ball - defends with a pleasing clunk of the bat
more swing for Pollock here, verging on bananarama. It's left alone outside off - a little bit too wide
beaten. Just a touch fuller, inviting the drive; the batsman accepts, goes for an emphatic cover drive but connects with thin air
too wide of the off stump this time
edged but it doesn't carry to Kemp at first slip. And he gets awkward bounce, the ball snaking through for a single
edged but again it doesn't carry to the slips and, with the extra pace of Ntini, it flies through the cordon and down to third man
no no no. Much too wide. We don't do wide
pushed to cover - and they set off for a single, which is never a safe option against South African fielders. A dive from the batsman saves him
too short - though it was his quickest delivery so far, 86.1mph - and it's left alone
Ntini's losing his lines here. This is on leg stump, and calmly pushed to midwicket
left alone once more outside off
cracking delivery. This pitch is made for Pollock. On off stump, cutting away just a touch, drawing the batsman forward who is beaten. Textbook bowling
oh that's even better - quicker, too - and it spits off a length away from the batsman who, again, is beaten
and again! Marvellous bowling here. Just a little wider, fuller, quicker still and again he swishes and misses
oh and he skips down the pitch, in a vain attempt to make contact with the ball. But misses
hurrah! It's defended on the front foot. Ah, leather on willow. Marvellous sound, that
and a pleasing defensive stroke ends a fascinating over
too short, too wide. Ntini looks pacey today, but the angle is too extreme and it's easily left alone
elegantly cover-driven on the front foot but straight to cover
just a little fuller this time but it's wide enough to leave well alone
fabulous ball, cutting him in half - it really cut back massively, forcing Boucher to dive to his right. Half an appeal from Boucher, but it was pretty limp
and there's the one which cuts away...this is much better from Ntini
excellent ball, but neatly played just tucking it to leg. Tortoise-like running only yields a single
no no, too wide. Lucky not to be called a wide, frankly
dropped into the off side - and they set off for a single. But it's going to be tight! And he throws himself across the line as the throw from mid-off was wide
my word! That's just crept over middle stump. He left it alone but, it kept very low - and Boucher took it on the bounce
neatly bowled again, on off stump and swinging back further into the let hander who clamps down on it
half a stride down the pitch and it's left alone. For once, that was just a touch too wide of the off stump
punched off the back foot
again a sign of indifferent bounce, as a shorter-length delivery creeps low and Boucher takes it on the bounce

terrific ball! Marvellous stuff from Ntini, cutting this away from the batsman who really isn't sure how on earth to play it. And no one can blame him. These conditions are tailor made (from Savile Row) for the bowlers
defended that one on the front foot
oh hello, like that one, Ntini shuffling the ball across the lefthander's bat, asking him to get an edge on it, Morgan declining politely
more angle on that than something very angled indeed - a size zero model's elbows? - anyway, wide down off
more of the same
angles that one across again, but closer this time, honing in on the right area
now then, he sniffed at that one and there was a snick, but it was bat hitting pad, and that's snapped up by the keeper, but Taufel isn't tested too much in declining that one
srtaight and that was played back
one to please coaches and fans of quick singles everywhere, just nudged down towards the covers and they run through neatly
Pollock huffing and puffing with the effort, lets out an "Ah" as he delivers a straight one, but for all his efforts, that's defended easily
eek, not a convincing shot from Morgan, a thick edge when he came out to prod that one way out in front of his body
came towards the bowler, but a play and a miss.
tickles that well off his legs
the wrong line and it's tucked off his hip
very well bowled, on middle-and-leg - just a hint that that was shaping away from him, but he was quick to clamp down on it and nudge it to leg
and that's guided down to gully who dives, and dives well to save a single
lovely ball on middle stump, just cutting a touch away from the left hander who is right behind it. Again evidence of wobbly bounce, as that spat up on him
cracked on the front foot square - oh, and a fine save from Gibbs at backward point. That was four were it not for him
driven uppishly, wide of the second slip - safe enough, and it zoots down to third man
shot. Pollock starts with a rare loose delivery on leg stump and Porterfield flicks it off his pads behind square, for four
and again he flicks it behind square but Ntini, jogging to his right from fine-leg, dives with natural athleticism to save four, as is the South African fielders' wont

on off stump but too short to be driving on the front foot, and he spoons it just over Kallis's head at extra cover...who takes a couple of steps backwards and a fine catch, tumbling to the ground as he does so
worked to mid-on for a single
too wide of the off stump from Pollock, and it's a nice sighter for O'Brien
on leg stump and nudged off his hip
pushed to backward point. No foot movement from O'Brien there but, sporting a good eye, it was easily worked down in front of point
ooh, he nearly got himself into a t-t-tangle there, defending off the back foot and the ball spun back, nearly onto his stump
on off stump, angling back into him and it's blocked out off the back foot
pushed back to the bowler
cracked on the front foot, thick outside edge which falls short of the wicketkeeper
pushed down to mid-on
flanged off the back foot wide of the slip, down to third man
and he comes charging down the pitch to a shorter delivery, attempting to hit it somewhere into the ocean, but the bowler saw him coming and sent it just a touch wider
very well bowled, cramping him for room and it's chopped down into the off side

drops this down into the off side off the back foot and immediately chirps "yep", setting off for a single. In comes the lurking Gibbs at point, flying in Rhodes-like but, most unlike him, fails to pick it up cleanly and Ireland are safe
worked off his legs with ease
wrapped on the pads but it's going down leg
hammered on the up but straight to mid-off. A misplaced-wallop, if you like
on leg stump, he turns it off his hip
dropped out into the off side and they scamper a single
and a play-and-a-miss outside off
timed on the front foot, but straight back to the bowler who, with large amounts of winnerness, scoops down to pick it up
poor delivery there - a village Hall, if you like - down the leg side and it's easily picked off, down to fine leg for four
that's filthy, miles wide of the off stump and O'Brien nearly ruptures something vital in trying to reach it
have some of that. Full and he swings over the line and plonks him for four, down to long on
drops this out into the off side
ooh, outside edge - lovely ball - and it flies down to third man. Neatly played, though, playing it as late as possible and guiding it.
that rather spat up at him, again played with soft hands
defended off the back foot to end the over
cut down to third man

shot. Really fine shot indeed, he absolutely laced that square of the wicket - timing it beautifully. Justin Kemp was caught asleep on the boundary and, despite a dive, it was four all the way (as opposed to four half of the way)
better, tighter line this time and it's defended out to cover
very well bowled, a quicker one which hurries past the batsman's meek backward-defensive-prod
again neatly square-driven out into the deep, but not quite as well placed
my word, extreme bounce there. O'Brien tries to uppercut it but it's far too short, and quick
dabbed down to third man. Neat, calm stroke
terrific delivery, beating O'Brien all ends up. Just cutting away from his flourishing drive
that's nasty. It's jumped off a length - a throat ball which O'Brien actually with great skill, never taking his eye off the ball
quality stroke. Never mind the swing and movement - he just jumped down the pitch and clobbered him over extra cover for four
guided, off the outside edge, down to third man. Intentionally played
and he rocks right back onto his stumps, angling it out to third man to steal a single. Excellent fielding and a scorching throw prevents any more
the wrong line, a leg-side drifter which is turned to short fine leg but Ntini can't save the single
just angled, using the pace of the ball, behind square for a single
huge appeal from Hall, from Boucher too, but it's turned down. No contact - appeared to be the bat hitting the pad which caused that dull-sounding thuddy noise
cut off the back foot to third man. Too wide.
dropped down into the leg side and they go for a single...but Morgan was ball watching and he has to scamper through to make his ground

what a vicious delivery, spitting up at him. He had nowhere to go, the ball skying to square leg who took a simple catch. Excellent change of pace there, but the wicket owed as much to the pitch's vagaries
punched off the back foot
run out to third man
cut back in off the seam and kept lowish. No idea why that wasn't out - only the umpire knows and he's not telling
a bouncer - Langeveldt was unimpressed with the lbw being turned down and that's how he shows it
batsman looks to scoop that out through mid-off, but doesn't get hold of it, an unconvincing shot, really, and the ball trickles back to the bowler
this one again pitches outside and cuts back in, but unlike earlier in the over, the batsman gets bat on it
slower ball, well disguised, and again it nibbles back in at the batsman, who bites back with a solid defence on the front foot
defended first up
round the wicket, by the way, and that's pinged in at the batsman on a tight line; it can only be defended right into the ground
drags that one a touch short and the batsman goes down the wicket and aerial - looking for the cow but not getting enough beef on it
bends that one in at the left hander again, who defends solidly enough
room outside off and that's slammed into the ground, the batsman again struggling with the timing, and playing it a touch too late to get anything substantial on it
a cheeky, lovely shot that one, the batsman getting into position early, rocking over his stumps to turn that right off his hips through fine. We liked that
comes down the track and tries to tee off with a flat-batted forward pull shot if you can imagine that which is swiped to mid-on - but again, there's a slight lack of timing
worked to square for an easy single
big air there all round - the bowler bustling in and flinging that one down and it pitched outside off, the batsman in his turn slicing right through the air
now that is good timing - stepped back and then into that shot to launch it over mid-off with a sweet strike, lovely

clever bowling in response, O'Brien through his shot too soon to that slower ball and the ball catches the back of the bat and flies up and into the hands of Gibbs at short midwicket. Catches don't come much simpler and South Africa are gaining momentum, and control, here
a leg-side very wide
pitches just outside off, on a decent length, and the batsman is squeezed for room, so he defends tightly
regulation line and length, regulation defence, regulation description
comes forward again, and defends again
a stifled shout as that one crashed into the pad but was straying down leg
outside off and Botha flashes a square-drive at that one to get off the mark in some style - not quite designer, but not Primark either
right up there and that's defended forward
on leg and that's driven well wide of mid-on, a nice-looking shot
over the wicket to the lefthander, doesn't quite find the line first up and there's a quick single of the shuffling variety
outside off and the batsman misses out on that - good timing with that cut behind point, but standard placement; that was straight to the fielder
cut back in from just outside off and that was defended down
byootifal shot that - White coming down and flamingo-whipping that one with a tennis slice of a drive that flies straight past the umpire
another boundary on the bounce, Kallis trying the bouncer in response and the batsman hooking that really well through fine leg. Top shot
on leg and that's tickled away off the legs
right up there, but the batsman nearly manages to work that from outside off to mid-on
ooh, Kemp and co forming their mouths into an "Ooh" shape there and with good reason, Kemp getting some away swing outside off stump which has the batsman fishing - just too wide for him to connect
worked behind square this time for a fuss-free single
edged through but Boucher, standing up, can't grasp it quickly and it hits his thigh and runs on for a quick single
driven forward
outside off and that's driven out to Kallis who's sweeping up on the off-side boundary
top edged that one to midwicket and it bounces agonisingly/fortuitously (delete as appropriate) in front of the fielder there
whipped off the legs, always a glorious-looking shot that
classical cover drive, but it does nothing more than sit there looking pretty, as the fielder snaps it up really easily
opens the face and they run a quick single which puts pressure on the fielder, Gibbs, who nearly allows overthrows. He misses with his shy and that's the 100 up
another good shot, that one's cleanly smote in front of midwicket - Kallis trying an offcutter, and it not working
this time Kallis tries to bang it in, but he gets no lift and that's driven down into the ground
defended on the spot
outside off and that's beefed in front of midwicket, the batsman opening up his arms and rolling them through the pull
pushed up there and that's defended down
'twas a brillig shout, but unfortunately for the bowler Taufel turns that one down - HawkEye has it snicking the off bail, yet you have to give the batsman the benefit, quite rightly too
hmm, not convincing, Botha goes to launch another of his straight slice-swipes, but the timing's all wrong
short ball, smashed square; have some of that
should have been two there, with that dab cut out through the covers, but Botha slipped on turning and had to get back to that crease
premeditated reverse sweep, poor connection
more premeditation, more reverse sweeping, and this time he connects - but still not on the middle - with a swish square
down on one knee and this time the sweep is orthodox
down on one knee and eases that out to point for the gentlest of singles
goes he softly into the light, hitting that full toss up to midwicket
dibbled that one down off the back foot into the covers and there's another single
decent delivery that from Kallis, round the wicket by the way, flirting through on a tempting length and come-to-bat eyes. Just failed to grace the edge
driven out to mid-on this time
the batsman moves back to give himself room to cut that ball to point - however... it dips on him, and is faster than he was expecting, so he cuts over it
bouncer, heading leg-ward though and Boucher misses it, and the batsmen capitalise
no... a short one - Kallis again trying to get some lift out of a dull track - and that's greyly worked to square
that's full and tempting, Botha's tempted and flights that up to cover for a simple catch
shuffles in and scurries that one in at the bat, the man rushing to defend forward
right up there, poked to mid-on and the batsmen chance a single, forcing the misfield and why not
Hall and his blue tail bustle in again but the batsman strides down to make that a half-volley and drive that one straight and aerial towards long-on, who collects on the bounce
slower delivery, well bowled, and that's defended down off the back foot
picks out the fielder again, this time with an easy drive to cover
low full toss outside off, but the bowler can count himself lucky to get away with that, the batsman cutting out to deep point
nips back in off the seam and that was driven out to Ntini on the extra-cover boundary
another easy catch; a short-pitched delivery and the batsman jumps up to cut that off the back foot, getting a top edge through to Boucher the poucher
short and strangled down leg-side for a golden duck. Langeveldt's grinning, as you would when you're on a hat-trick
defended down and he couldn't have played that any better if he was wielding a barn wall, nevermind a barn door, with a forward defence
outside off and that one sits up, hangs there and offers the batsman plenty of time to cut that out just inside the point boundary
slower ball and that's driven to mid-on, the batsman having to adjust his timing and not quite managing to do so
driven to long-off for a straightforward single
another slower ball, and there was a run-out chance then, but that was a poor throw in, like when you throw with the wrong hand, and missed the target completely
driven out to mid-off
another shy and another miss and there's a whole speed-dating event's worth of singles out there
well bowled, a dot, and the batsman cuts into the ground, completely missing the ball
a flash and a miss
short and that's driven from off high and higher - travelling all the way over long-on
chipped up over to cover
outside off and the batsman again cuts his bat down into the ground
pushed right up there, but that's well dug out with a lovely cover drive through, well, you know
smashed away behind point for a one-bounce four
slower ball, good delivery, outside off and the batsman is tempted to slash at that - he misses
outside off, drags that short and that's well held by the steward over the extra-cover boundary
driven into the ground and the pace comes right off the ball
driven into the foot and that brings up the 150 with an unconvincing single
outside off and that was cut into the ground, again
driven forward and that ends the innings

inn2.comm: on middle stump, defended on the front foot
angling into the right hander who is hit on the pad. Perhaps done by pace there
very wide, wide enough to be called a wide, and the umpire calls it a wide. A feast of wideness

gone! It was short and wide, and deserved to be clobbered through the covers, but it jumped up a touch, causing his cut to fly to William Porterfield at backward point. And though he juggled it, he remained calm and took it on the second attempt
terrific ball! Just cutting back into the right hander who fends at it, the ball zooting through to the keeper
but it's a touch wider this time, allowing the batsman a sighter
terrific line again - McGrath-like, in fact, which might seem overly generous...but not by much. Just outside off, a nagging line
but Dave wobbles it wide of the off stump and it's easily left alone
well, Smith won't miss out on those - and though he only gets a single, it was a neat tuck off his pads
a fine shot, just stroking it through extra cover. Too wide; dispatched
better line on middle stump, Kallis tries to work it to leg but can't time or place it
late swing for Dave there, but too wide of the off stump to trouble Kallis who shoulders arms
the wrong line again from Langford-Smith, Kallis turns him behind square for a single
the younger Rankin shows his more experienced partner, Langford-Smith, the right line - just outside off, on a good length
well bowled again, this is an excellent start from Rankin. Kallis went back, tried to force it off the back foot but got a thick inside edge into his pad
ever-so-slightly shorter this time, giving Kallis a touch more time. Back he goes onto his stumps, defending off the back foot
swing-and-a-miss. Kallis getting frustrated? Unlikely. Either way, an injudicious shot from him, never moving his feet and swinging hopelessly at it
clever bowling. Not quite a bouncer, but short enough to cause evasion tactics from Kallis who swayed out of the way like the massive swaying winner he is
that is an absolute corker from Rankin. Harmison-at-his-best-like length, spitting up at Kallis's chest and cutting away from him, he fended waftily at it, and it flew through to O'\Brien
punched back to Langford-Smith who skips across the pitch to his right, fields with his right hand and shatters Smith's stumps
Smith is firmly behind this straight delivery, on a nagging length, defending it out to cover and roaring "no" to Kallis

Smith goes forward, then back, prods it down into the off side. "Yes. NO!" is the cry, and the correct one too as Ireland's enthusiastic fielders swarm onto the ball like a pride of lions scenting a kill
pushed off his pads to midwicket but he can't place it
an attempted slower ball which Smith reads, and calmly turns to fine-leg
beautiful stroke. Standing tall, almost arrogantly so, and literally caressing it through the covers. So often cricket's most turgid of batsmen, so far today he seems in pleasingly fluent form
but it's on Smith's favoured leg stump and easily nurdled for a single to leg
commandingly, dangerously cut for four. That went like a tracer bullet - scorching across the outfield
short, but straighter this time and Kallis honours it with a backward defence
and a good length here from Rankin, drawing Kallis forward who plants a heavy front foot down the pitch, presenting the face of the bat to one attacking his off stump
too straight from Rankin allowing Kallis to stun it to leg for a single
angled off the back foot
ooh close - a swing and a miss there and Smith shakes his head in utter disgust (at the shot. Not the ball or the bowler)
marvellous stroke there, pinging it past Dave - dead straight - for four. Timed that beautifully
powerfully clipped to leg but Morgan is excellent at short midwicket, diving to his preferred left and saving at least two
crunched to mid-off
a shimmy down the pitch and a skying-slap over long-off for four
cut past point
good line from Rankin, on middle stump - perhaps a touch too straight, but this is a mature opening spell so far. As all his opening spells in this Cup have been
bullishly worked to leg for a zero
and that rather hurries onto Smith, but he's well back in his crease and has enough time to jab down on it. Kept a little low, that
but Rankin strays here, like a city cat, down the leg side and Smith turns it away for a single
Kallis punches to mid-on but...straight to mid-on
chopped down past point
bottom edge - very, very nearly bowled Kallis there. It was an ugly wide, but Kallis flung his bat at it without really caring where it'd go. And it nutmegged the keeper for four
crashed off the back foot, square, but it's a no ball
a touch of inswing for Mooney - but not a lot - and Smith just punches it to short midwicket
good length here, cramping Smith for room who works it to leg
and Smith is fed up with all this prodding malarkey; he swings it over mid-off, but only just over his head and it flobbles down to long-off, slowing as it goes
good grief, he laced that one. That is quite fantastically hit, on the up, square of the wicket. No one moved
excellent response, forcing the defensive
oh he's timed that, Smith, but it's not the place to bowl at him - on his legs, and he pings it down the ground for four

and that'll be four more - and a no-ball - as Smith works it to leg, again with good timing. Jeremy Bray sprints across, dives, and with limbs seemingly everywhere it was a failed - but good - attempt
short, wide, Smith takes a step outside leg to hit him into a nearby island but misses
studiously worked through midwicket for two, for three? No, they decide against it
on off stump and Smith gives it due respect, just blocking it out carefully
well that rather hurries onto Smith there who defends off the back foot
worked to leg
punched on the front foot, with a high front elbow, to cover
massively wide, Kallis actually does rather well to reach it - let alone time it. And he does both things very well. Well done him. Slapping it past point
and Smith goes for a punchy punch but it's about as effective as a chocolate teapot
oh, very well pulled. Mooney dropped it in short and Smith had seemingly ages to select where to pull it
punched out into the covers. But a no-ball...
again too short, again wide of the leg stump and Smith paddles it for four. Easy. This is poor, poor bowling
cracked into the covers
and he starts well, with one just outside off and it's pushed out to cover
on the off stump and defended on the front foot
and back he goes to defend off the back foot
elegantly driven by Smith, albeit with his head rolling backwards
pushed back to the bowler
and he does whack it, but can't quite time it past point
on off stump, angling away and Smith cuts to nowhere
full and straight, Smith just times it through cover
oh and a swing and a miss, O'Brien whips off the bails for no reason whatsoever. And Simon Taufel jogs across to pick them up
marvellous piece of variations there, a neat slower ball swinging into Smith
Smith wheels this to deep midwicket
close! A play-and-a-miss, Kallis trying to late-cut it. But missed.

what a catch! That is a quite brilliant, reflex snaffle from Johnston. A full toss which Smith hammered back to him, no more than four or five inches above the ground, and Johnston plucked it out of the air
a good one first up, spearing into Gibbs whose head falls away - but fortunately it's attached to his body, and he survives to live another ball
pushed out to cover
again Gibbs's head falls to the off side as he tries to work it through midwicket. And misses
oh no no no, don't bowl there. Gibbs flangs it over cover with freeflowing goodness, available at Tescos and all good retailers, for four
pushed back to mid-on
dabbed down to gully
comes forward and defends that one on the front foot
outside off, enough room to cut, and Kallis shapes to late cut but doesn't get hold of it as he would have liked
better ball, nipping back off the seam in at the batsman who defends it down
outside off again, a touch more room and Kallis times that ... right to cover. Made a lovely sound, though
another neat 'clock' as that one's eased to long-off and Kallis nabs the strike
on leg and that's driven away through midwicket and runs all the way along the ground
angling in on middle and that's driven, deliberately without much power, into the cover region
outside off and the batsman waits to squirt that down to a wide third man
short and the batsman jabs his bat down on that one, with just enough room to do so, as he carves that into midwicket
driven to mid-off
nips back off the seam, raps the pads, but high - still, O'Brien makes a loud, long appeal behind the sticks, taking the consonants out of 'Howzat' as he does so
sticks that one on a good length, but the batsman manages to drive easily enough to cover and they jog through a single
straighter, and dibbled down off the legs into the leg-side
slower delivery that couldn't have been more telegraphed and the batsman latches on to it with a cover-drive, but even so he doesn't time it properly
worked to mid-on
swings in at Gibbs who doesn't really have much room to play that one, neither forward, nor back, but in the porch and he shunts it forward
nearly takes the edge here, good little spell from Botha
played off the back foot behind point
similar ball, similar shot and it's all about "Waiting!" for the batsmen
dragged down and that's another great catch! This one hit the bottom of the bat, the ball on too quickly for Gibbs looking to hit it over midwicket, and that's snapped low and tidily indeed
on off, short, and that's defended down first up
up there, jinked into short midwicket and will they run? "No!"
over the wicket, by the way, and that's a straight bouncer, Prince ducking accordingly
slower ball, that's driven to cover, and there's a vitality and vigour (if that's not a tautology) about Ireland right now
pushed up there and the batsman defends right over
oh, awkward delivery there, floating in low, with a bit of inswing, and Kallis must defend that
cut away, later than he meant to, but he still hits the gap and the pressure's eased in one swish of the bat
driven with all the time in the world to long-on
that was temporarily interesting for the fielders there, the batsman stopping on the shot and popping it up towards cover, but it lands in space
defended down
driven out to cover for an easy single
drags that a touch short but at this level you can't give away any length whatsoever and that's tucked off the hips in front of square
a half-volley on leg and that's driven out to long-on
comes forward and drives that straight to cover
dropped and is that this match's definitive turning point? Rankin uses some very fruity language in self-remonstration, a low drive back to him, but should have been held
spins that one in at the lefthander, tucking him right up and making him play with a forward defensive
turns that one in again, but he gets over it and works it out in front of square
on middle and leg and that's worked over into short midwicket
straight and that's turned again to square
big shout and McCallan can't work out why that's not been given - missing leg I reckon
outside off and that's poked into short midwicket
Dave overpitches but gets away with it, the batsman stopping on the shot with a drive to mid-off
that one looked to be heading down leg as the batsman swishes it square
driven without any power to the leg side
short and that's bunted off the bottom of the bat with a square cut that he just laces, smashing into that one like a tennis forehand
drives out, this time with more orthodoxy, to just inside the cover boundary
outside off and driven to cover
oh and dropped - a top-edge off a sweep with Johnston running forward and just misjudging the low catch
straight, and driven to mid-on
round the wicket by the way and that's swept round to square
swept finely to fine leg
worked out to square
pitched right up there, tucking him up, and that's defended forward
on middle and leg and a sweep to the on-side brings up his 61st one-day fifty
rushed up there, but there's a touch of width and it's driven from off into the leg-side
straight, a touch short, and that's eased out on the front foot through midwicket
short and pulled gracefully, but without much power, behind square
pushed up there by Dave and that's driven out to cover for a single to bring up Nelson
driven back to the bowler who picks it up tidily
on leg and that's worked in front of square
driven back to the bowler
nicely played behind the wicket with a reverse sweep
nice flight and that's driven to cover
comes down with intent and that's driven to mid-on
dragged it a touch short and that's worked to short midwicket
over the wicket to the lefthander and that's defended forward
over the wicket and that's worked to midwicket
cut in off the seam and that's worked out to cover
slower ball and that's worked down to short midwicket
cheeky sweep, good timing and that's worked behind square right out towards the boundary
outside off and that's late cut behind point
swept fine
and Prince skips down the pitch, knocking it to mid-on
and he tries to work it to leg, the ball bobbling out to the leg side
and there's Prince's first four. Well done that man. He hit it several miles in the air, thus preventing it from going for six. Super shot over long-off
ooh Prince was late on that; a thick inside edge brings him a single
pushed to mid-on
on leg stump, Prince slinks it around the corner
defended on the front foot
and it's nicely swept but straight to square leg
that's out, surely. No - that's why I'm not an umpire. Much quicker ball which raps him on the pad
pushed to cover for a single
sweeps this around the corner
bash. Prince comes down the track, smacking this one over mid-on for an authoritative four
take that. A replica of the previous shot, but this time Prince holds his pose
quicker and straighter and defended
on off stump and Kallis shines it to mid-off
eased down to long-on
on off stump, and it's defended cautiously
and it's pushed down the ground
really sweetly driven, but without perfect placement into the covers. Excellently fielded, and a good throw prevents two
smacked back past the bowler
guided down to gully
quicker, but a full toss and crashed into the covers
full and straight, Prince just pumps it to mid-on
pushed down the ground. South Africa happy to tick off the singles here. No red-inking or anything
defensively driven past the bowler
lovely crisp clunk of that bat as Prince pulls it just over midwicket, and just wide of mid-on
driven neatly down the ground
ah that's the Kallis we know and love. An expansive, flourishing drive straight to deep extra cover for a single
on leg stump and it's worked by Prince through midwicket
neatly swept around the corner
gloriously driven out to deep extra, but just a single
defended out to cover
nicely bowled, cutting this into Kallis who blocks it out on the front foot
stroked to long-off
and it's punched to mid-off to end the over
a swing-and-a-miss from Kallis
a huge full toss which Kallis does well to pull
Prince cracks this off the back foot, and that should be four at a wide long-off - but no, a superb piece of fielding from Bray out there, with Ronaldo-like footwork, prevents four
and Prince finishes it off in style with a terrific lofted shot over long-on
